Okay, this game has a few pros and a few cons. [i]Before[/i] I get into those, I'd like to make it clear that [b]I do recommend and enjoy this game.[/b] Now that that's out of the way:

[h1]Pros[/h1]
1. Really fun to play multiplayer, whether it's friends or strangers. The experience is always enjoyable.

2. The art style is charming.

3. The game can run on computers of all varieties, including potatoes.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
1. The grind is [b]INSANE.[/b] If you miss quota [i]once,[/i] say goodbye to [u]everything[/u] you've worked so hard to achieve. Personally, I like to collect new jumpsuits for my crew and I, so watching my collection reset time and time again is really upsetting. Also, this makes me less and less likely to play more as each time I get further, it's just another roll of the dice.

2. It's much harder to play single-player than it should be. Quotas don't adjust for the number of players in the slightest, so if you're further in the game, you better grab some friends.

3. Death is too fast. I've heard this complaint before, and I stand behind it. Dying in this game is too unavoidable and too easy. Yes, the clips are funny, but there has to be a middle ground.

4. The inventory is [i]so[/i] small. Yeah, it works when playing alone, but when you're with friends? One slot will be used up on a flashlight, another for a walkie-talkie, and maybe even a [b]third[/b] for a weapon, key, jetpack, etc. At that point, you can only grab one thing at a time, which is insanely frustrating.

[h2]My Suggestions[/h2]
1. I think that when you die, all your equipment (such as flashlights, walkies, and shovels) should reset. However, the jumpsuits you purchased should stay attached to that save permanently. "But bro, that means we'll have unlimited jumpsuits!" No. Add a reasonable maximum number on the rack, as well as the option to sell existing jumpsuits. This way, the collection can stay with you, but change over time.

2. On the health matter, there's a few possible solutions. On one hand, you could add a cheap med-kit item, but you'd also have to increase inventory space by a [b]minimum[/b] of 1 to compensate.

3. Either increase health or stamina. If neither of those, make the enemies less insta-kill.

4. Increase the inventory size. Either that or have designated slots for things like the flashlight and walkie.

Thank you for your time.

Lethal Company is the only game where your job description is literally:
“Go into the abandoned facility full of nightmares. Bring back trash. Try not to die. (You will die.)”

The Company sends you to moons that look like a post-apocalyptic IKEA parking lot, and the moment you step outside, the universe politely informs you that every living creature wants to end your employment contract AND your spinal column.

Let’s talk about the monsters—because these things feel like the devs opened the “deepest human fears” wiki and just said “yes.”

The Bracken (a.k.a. The Gaslight Gatekeep Girlboss Vine Man)

This creature does not kill you immediately.
No no. That would be merciful.
The Bracken just stalks you silently like it’s scrolling your social media history. You turn around? Nothing. You turn back? He’s in your personal space asking if you’ve accepted death into your heart today.
He breaks your neck in the exact same vibe as someone closing a book they’re bored of.

The Forest Keeper (a.k.a. Daddy Long-Legs With Anger Issues)

This big wooden disaster sounds like a tree being bullied by the wind. You’ll hear it before you see it—boom… boom…
Then you do see it, and suddenly you’re sprinting like you never have in your life trying not to get slurped up like a Go-Gurt.
He grabs you, stares at you for exactly one (1) second, then eats you like a mozzarella stick.

The Coil-Head (a.k.a. The Reason I Now Sleep with the Lights On)

Oh, the Coil-Head.
Imagine a mannequin.
Now imagine it moves only when you’re not looking, like a horror version of peak hide-and-seek competitiveness.
The entire “fight” is just you backing away slowly while your teammates yell:
“WHO TURNED AROUND?! WHO BLINKED?! WHICH ONE OF YOU BETRAYED GOD?!”

Bunker Spiders (a.k.a. Homeowners Association Threats)

They live in corners. They wait. They judge.
You don’t see them at first—then suddenly you’re in a sticky web, rethinking every decision that led you here, including your choice of friends, career, and rental agreement.
Every encounter feels like being mugged by a hairy dinner plate.

Eyeless Dogs (a.k.a. Sonic the Hedgehog But Traumatized)

These beasts patrol the outside like nature’s security guards, except they hate all life and sound like they’ve swallowed a train whistle.
They can’t see you, so you think staying quiet helps… until your friend accidentally coughs and suddenly the whole planet is sprinting toward you at Mach 2.

Meanwhile, your teammates will cause 90% of the deaths.

You’ll be sneaking carefully through a dark corridor, whispering, “Guys… I think something’s here,” and then your buddy behind you just decides to break into full Broadway tap-dance mode, summoning EVERYTHING within a mile.

You will also absolutely leave your friends to die.
Not intentionally at first.
But the moment you hear footsteps behind you that aren’t YOUR footsteps, morality evaporates.
You run.
You don’t look back.
You show up at the ship alone.
“Where’s everyone else?”
“…collecting scrap.”

Voice chat makes the game 10x funnier and 10x worse. Hearing someone scream “BIG GUY BIG GUY BIG GUY” before cutting to radio silence should legally count as cardio.

And at the end of this nightmare?
The Company looks at the three pounds of bent metal you risked your life for and says:

“Huh. That’s it?”

If I ever meet the CEO I’m dropkicking him into an Eyeless Dog pit.

And yet—
You keep going back.
You keep dying.
You keep selling your friends’ corpses because Company quota does not care about your grief.

So, here's the deal with Lethal Company.

This game is a chaotic co-op and a factory for the most absurd, laugh-out-loud gaming moments. The concept is quite simple: you're a space-faring scrap stalker-collector for a shady Company, risking your life on haunted bum's planets to meet a profit quota. The atmosphere is thick and the lore is intriguingly sparse.

When you have a crew that knows what they're doing, it's all you need. It's a game where communication isn't just helpful - it's your primary survival tool. This is also where the game shines as a social platform. I've met amazing people from all over the world, and joining a lobby based on language is a fantastic way to practice and have fun.

What you should consider is - you will die. A lot. You'll watch your teammate attempt a graceful leap over a Slime, only to be consumed by it. You'll get snatched by a tentacle because someone didn't call out the noise. Without a coordinated team (or friends you bring along), the game can feel brutally unfair and short-lived.

Lethal Company doesn't hold your hand, and it punishes you for not knowing its secrets. If you don't have the monster behaviors and map layouts memorized, your run often ends in a two-minute sprint straight into the loving embrace of the Electric Bees. It forces you to either study the wiki or play enough to become a burden to your team until you learn. This can be a major turn-off for casual players.

It's a game that can absolutely hook you and provide unforgettable moments. Just be prepared for a rocky start and know that your team is the real endgame content.

"Lethal Company" is an amusing, fun, and scary game, best played at late hours with friends!

I feel as if "the more, the merrier" couldn't be more true than with this game. It is especially fun to play with a full squad, and some of the monsters are certainly geared towards the idea of multiple players being in the lobby. 

I enjoy that there's a big variety in moons, monsters, and scrap that make every run feel unique, as well as all the lore tidbits stuffed into the world, which I can't wait to learn more about! I think it still comes off as a pretty complete game, despite still being a work-in-progress and lots of features/lore still being added in, just with a few areas that you definitely feel like should have something there! 

It's an easy game to lose time in, because there are so many different ways to play or customize your experience by visiting different combinations of moons and changing up routes, and it's ultra-satisfying to build up those scrap numbers, collect upgrades, and deck out the ship. 

I find it very immersive with the thorough logs; however, I recognize the lore is probably not the most unique thing. Still, I think the designs and game dynamics of the monsters definitely steal the show. There's a lot of potential for story here too, and you can tell there was a lot of care and effort put into the game. 

The overall community also does a lot to build this game up and help it stand out against other games that have a similar style/format. A lot of fun challenges have come from the streaming community, and I think it's fascinating that this game, while there are still speed-runners, has a robust community of high-quota runners that hype up the game's potential as well.

Great co-op experience, be it in a private party or with complete strangers. Some may find it horror, but I'd say that it's more of a psychological thriller due to the tension and the suspense that one may feel not knowing when they'd encounter - and preferably counter - the creatures, and if they'd get spotted by them at an inappropriate time (e.g. carrying a pricey, heavy double-handed item that could help you make the quota while the Thumper starts chasing you and it is close to the end of a working day). Knowledge is power, and depending on the player who understands how the creatures, the loot, the bought products and the maps work, one can have tons of fun or little to no fun with all of that information in mind. Spontaneity lies in the randomized spawning points and time stamps for both the loot and the creatures, and otherwise, it is the same routine of trying to make it out alive while bringing as much loot to the ship as possible. I personally really like routine and don't get bored easily, so I never fell out of love with this game. Make sure to meet high expectations! You wouldn't want to upset the Company... or Jeb for that matter.

Shout out to Zeekerss, that one Furry game developer that spent time in his dark corner to research and make this entertaining jewel! And on that note, shout out to creative, ingenuous Furries! You're giving us more reasons to be loud 'n' proud!

A well known survival loot game, this platform is able to deliver a multitude of fun for up to 4 players as they scramble around various maps to find 'scrap', avoid monsters, and sell them to the entity for profit. Despite being an indie game with laughably low graphics quality (think Minecraft), this platform is able to turn these disadvantages around by advertising itself as a VERY light-weight and rapid-loading game with minimal computer and temperature stresses. 

Up to 4 players are placed on particular 'moon' maps of one's choosing, and all have access to proximity voice and text chat. Clearly distinct and important items are brightly colored to contrast with the surrounding background, and more valuable loot are usually smaller or darker colored in nature. A variety of different monsters all require different strategies for management, adding to the tension, with some being able to more punish solo players than others. Tools become paramount in managing one's playthrough and can be picked up from dead players to prevent permanent loss. All of these aspects combine together as players eagerly or terrifyingly shout at their teammates for instructions or assistance as they strive to gather enough scrap and survive their moon maps. 

As mentioned earlier, graphics are ridiculously low quality, but it is clear that the game was deliberately designed as such. Still however, this may prove unattractive to some players who seek visual beauty and details. As players progress through more and more moons and scrap selling, they will eventually hit near impossible scrap goals, guarenteeing their inevitable game-over and restart, which may prove discouraging to some. Having a mic is almost a requirement, as most hosts often kick players who do not have any. The learning curve is quite sharp, as this game provides minimal hand holding and instead kicks their baby chick players out of the nest to die and learn anew. 

At the end of the day, this light-weight and computer friendly game provides an easy-to-pick up platformer with simple and straightforward goals. Even the most veteran players remain vulnerable to death, as the focus revolves not around combat, but survival and looting. Highly recommend with friends with mics, and for its relatively low price and computer stress, this game is a must-try for even the most casual players.

I will try to be very objective in this review. This game has brought me many hours of fun and enjoyment with my friends. However, I can’t turn a blind eye to the current state of things. The game, as it stands right now, is very lacking—no significant updates, extremely basic “changes,” and a complete lack of effort to keep players engaged. Sadly, it seems to be heading down the same path as many other indie games. What I mean by that is it appears to be stuck in Early Access hell forever.

It wouldn’t really be an issue if the game were free-to-play or sold as a complete product. My biggest gripe with all of this is that this is no longer a small project. The game has sold well and even had a collaboration with Epic Games. The means were there to continue developing the project and not leave players in the dark for so long. However, the predictable choice was to almost fully abandon the game and focus on other things while the game you paid for rots in Early Access limbo.

In conclusion, as of right now, I cannot recommend the game unless it somehow gets back on track.

An expired flavour-of-the-month game.

The basic graphics work because (like the DOS games) I think it leaves something to the imagination. The important thing was the small file size, allowing you to quickly download it and jump into a session with friends.

The gameplay feels chaotic though - you can get lost, and lose communication with teammates, and get killed instantly when you go through a door. The flashlight (if you even have one) only works for about a minute, which is frustrating when so much of the environment is pitch black, while other games handle lighting systems better (Aliens Vs Predator 2000, Half-Life). The lack of Workshop support is awkward, as mods could probably add value to the gameplay.

I can't take it too seriously - it's the kind of game to have a laugh with friends, but does anyone still play it? I've had fun with it, but when I tried it in 2025, I only managed to get into one lobby, but the host seemed to be kicking everyone. At £8.50 it's more expensive than Garry's Mod, and certainly offers less value than Gmod as a place to goof around.
